data.title: Conscience Point
data.meta_description: Docuseek2 is the source for essential social issue and documentary film for education, with over 2,300 titles in all major disciplines.
data.text:
WEBVTT

00:00:01.284 --> 00:00:04.975

(mellow music)

00:00:17.500 --> 00:00:22.483

(soft music)

00:01:14.237 --> 00:01:15.464

- [Rebecca] Morning.

00:01:15.464 --> 00:01:17.214

Hi, how\'s everything?

00:01:24.959 --> 00:01:26.990

Good morning, Grandmother.

00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:28.897

Are we ready to get ready?

00:01:28.897 --> 00:01:29.730

Okay.

00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:30.981

Good morning, Boopsie.

00:01:30.981 --> 00:01:31.900

(speaking foreign language)

00:01:31.900 --> 00:01:32.883

My baby.

00:01:36.830 --> 00:01:38.970

Henry, hurry, hurry, hurry.

00:01:40.805 --> 00:01:41.638

Give me one second.

00:01:41.638 --> 00:01:42.471

He\'ll be right here.

00:01:51.528 --> 00:01:52.646

- [Nasha] Love you.

00:01:52.646 --> 00:01:53.563

- Love you.

00:01:56.700 --> 00:01:57.900

- [Nasha] See you later.

00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:05.600

- Shinnecock Nation, it\'s a small tribe.

00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:08.630

On the reservation, 500 people or so

00:02:10.161 --> 00:02:13.310

and we\'re surrounded by the wealthy folks

00:02:13.310 --> 00:02:15.790

who are living on our land.

00:02:15.790 --> 00:02:19.230

As native people, you

feel a responsibility

00:02:19.230 --> 00:02:22.410

to your ancestral territory,

00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:24.890

to protect the land as much as we can.

00:02:24.890 --> 00:02:27.490

It\'s nearly impossible in this day and age

00:02:27.490 --> 00:02:29.563

but we\'re still gonna do the best we can.

00:02:34.809 --> 00:02:37.892

(quiet upbeat music)

00:02:39.657 --> 00:02:41.689

- [Group] We pledge allegiance to the Flag

00:02:41.689 --> 00:02:43.562

of the United States of America

00:02:43.562 --> 00:02:44.410

and to the Republic--

00:02:44.410 --> 00:02:46.670

- [Man] We\'re a maritime community.

00:02:46.670 --> 00:02:49.930

People are coming here with

large amounts of money.

00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:53.030

The conflict now is over development.

00:02:53.030 --> 00:02:55.040

- More often than not, I hardly recognize

00:02:55.040 --> 00:02:56.530

this place I call home.

00:02:56.530 --> 00:03:00.300

- In the last 10 years we\'ve

lost right-of-ways to the bay.

00:03:00.300 --> 00:03:02.500

- This property was

transferred from the town

00:03:02.500 --> 00:03:05.633

without the town board

understanding this agreement.

00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:08.910

- You watch what happens

with all this preserve land.

00:03:08.910 --> 00:03:10.310

They\'re gonna be encroaching on it.

00:03:10.310 --> 00:03:12.140

They\'re gonna be putting

driveways through it.

00:03:12.140 --> 00:03:15.520

- [Man] That guy down

there changed that place

00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:17.027

into his Hamptons

00:03:17.027 --> 00:03:18.487

and you took our Hamptons.

00:03:18.487 --> 00:03:20.590

- But I don\'t feel so alone today.

00:03:20.590 --> 00:03:22.690

I feel what the farmers are feeling.

00:03:22.690 --> 00:03:24.140

I feel what the people are feeling.

00:03:24.140 --> 00:03:26.173

And we\'re gonna do something about this.

00:03:36.260 --> 00:03:38.393

Oh my gosh, it\'s so beautiful today.

00:03:41.672 --> 00:03:42.505

A little bluejay.

00:03:42.505 --> 00:03:43.590

No, that\'s a woodpecker.

00:03:43.590 --> 00:03:45.040

What is that?

00:03:45.040 --> 00:03:48.053

These are mostly clamshells.

00:03:49.510 --> 00:03:51.960

We are at Conscience Point.

00:03:51.960 --> 00:03:54.930

This is where our Shinnecock ancestors

00:03:54.930 --> 00:03:59.230

met the first Europeans, pilgrims.

00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:00.670

Some people say, you know,

00:04:00.670 --> 00:04:03.990

well my family\'s been here for

four, five, six generations.

00:04:03.990 --> 00:04:08.990

Well, we\'re been here

400 generations plus.

00:04:09.150 --> 00:04:10.410

As far as land was,

00:04:10.410 --> 00:04:14.680

it was just a total

different way of thinking.

00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:17.523

Like to own your land,

we\'re just caretakers.

00:04:18.500 --> 00:04:20.850

I love this spot because it is beautiful

00:04:20.850 --> 00:04:24.050

and it is preserved land over there

00:04:24.050 --> 00:04:26.630

but it\'s a good place to

commune with the ancestors

00:04:26.630 --> 00:04:28.670

and let them know how much we honor

00:04:28.670 --> 00:04:30.310

and respect and care for them

00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:32.810

and try to be good people

00:04:35.157 --> 00:04:36.136

and think about them.

00:04:36.136 --> 00:04:38.553

(soft music)

00:04:46.090 --> 00:04:48.450

For at least the last century

00:04:48.450 --> 00:04:52.080

the Hamptons has been

a spot for the wealthy

00:04:52.080 --> 00:04:56.320

to get away from the hustle and bustle.

00:04:56.320 --> 00:04:58.300

They can drive their limousines

00:04:58.300 --> 00:05:01.110

right past this indigenous community

00:05:01.110 --> 00:05:03.963

and not even know that we exist.

00:05:07.860 --> 00:05:09.810

- We\'re a small community.

00:05:09.810 --> 00:05:13.150

We\'re finite in this greater

community of the Hamptons.

00:05:13.150 --> 00:05:16.410

The land base that we have here

00:05:16.410 --> 00:05:19.290

is approximately 1,200 acres.

00:05:19.290 --> 00:05:23.260

This is a small piece of

our original territory.

00:05:23.260 --> 00:05:25.070

Our original territory extended

00:05:25.070 --> 00:05:27.080

from the East Hampton town line

00:05:27.080 --> 00:05:29.470

all the way to the Brookhaven town line.

00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:32.000

One of the first things

that we did as a people

00:05:32.000 --> 00:05:35.320

in 1640 when the first settlers arrived,

00:05:35.320 --> 00:05:40.070

is we gave them eight

square miles of land to use

00:05:40.070 --> 00:05:43.000

which is now current

day Southampton Village

00:05:43.000 --> 00:05:45.310

and we\'ve paid the

price for it ever since.

00:05:45.310 --> 00:05:46.770

Here we sit, you know,

00:05:46.770 --> 00:05:49.140

in the middle of lifestyles

of the rich and famous

00:05:49.140 --> 00:05:52.340

and yet 60% of our people in our community

00:05:52.340 --> 00:05:54.610

are below the poverty level.

00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:55.782

That\'s a problem.

00:05:55.782 --> 00:06:00.516

(soft music)

00:06:08.584 --> 00:06:11.060

- You know Modell\'s Shopping stores?

00:06:11.060 --> 00:06:12.160

That\'s Modell\'s house.

00:06:13.660 --> 00:06:16.262

It\'s funny the people that live out here.

00:06:16.262 --> 00:06:18.440

You see this house right here,

00:06:18.440 --> 00:06:20.160

house on an acre?

00:06:20.160 --> 00:06:22.070

That\'s eight million dollars right there.

00:06:22.070 --> 00:06:23.490

That huge house back there

00:06:23.490 --> 00:06:26.370

I sold to a 29 year old 10 years ago

00:06:26.370 --> 00:06:28.550

for 15 million dollars.

00:06:28.550 --> 00:06:31.115

The owner of Coach just built that house.

00:06:31.115 --> 00:06:34.680

He paid 25 million dollars

for the land right there.

00:06:34.680 --> 00:06:37.530

And a farmer sold it that

owned it for hundreds of years.

00:06:39.860 --> 00:06:40.973

It\'s a crazy place.

00:06:42.500 --> 00:06:44.780

Almost everybody who\'s successful

00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:48.080

financially in New York,

they wanna be here.

00:06:48.080 --> 00:06:50.550

So when you have a lot of people chasing

00:06:50.550 --> 00:06:53.673

not that much property

it just keeps going up.

00:06:55.620 --> 00:06:57.110

But there\'s something about it out here

00:06:57.110 --> 00:06:58.360

that they all wanna come.

00:07:00.238 --> 00:07:02.932

I just happened to enter

real estate in 1996

00:07:02.932 --> 00:07:05.960

and I call it the best

20 years in real estate

00:07:05.960 --> 00:07:07.720

in 10,000 years.

00:07:07.720 --> 00:07:10.530

We were selling 18 million

dollar houses in \'06 and \'07

00:07:10.530 --> 00:07:13.260

to hedge fund managers

like they were candy.

00:07:13.260 --> 00:07:17.290

Being a finance guy, I like

to turn things quickly.

00:07:17.290 --> 00:07:18.890

I call it the velocity of money.

00:07:20.840 --> 00:07:23.710

The big complaint out

here is overdevelopment

00:07:23.710 --> 00:07:24.850

and I agree with them.

00:07:24.850 --> 00:07:26.080

But people are gonna continue

00:07:26.080 --> 00:07:28.150

to want homes and buy homes.

00:07:28.150 --> 00:07:29.870

Doesn\'t the next generation deserve

00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:31.583

a house, pool, and tennis in the Hamptons?

00:07:31.583 --> 00:07:32.983

I mean, that\'s how I see it.

00:07:34.520 --> 00:07:37.270

(waves crashing)

00:07:40.108 --> 00:07:41.630

- This is a very unique area.

00:07:41.630 --> 00:07:45.670

Besides having a population

of close to 60,000,

00:07:45.670 --> 00:07:47.210

that\'s a year round population.

00:07:47.210 --> 00:07:50.690

In the summer months it quadruples

00:07:50.690 --> 00:07:52.510

and it\'s very culturally diverse

00:07:52.510 --> 00:07:54.280

and economically diverse.

00:07:54.280 --> 00:07:56.530

We have some of the wealthiest

people on the planet,

00:07:56.530 --> 00:07:59.050

heads of multinational corporations.

00:07:59.050 --> 00:08:01.470

The one percent of the one percenters.

00:08:01.470 --> 00:08:03.810

Then we also have very modest people

00:08:03.810 --> 00:08:06.410

who work two or three jobs to deal with

00:08:06.410 --> 00:08:08.560

the high cost of living here.

00:08:08.560 --> 00:08:11.500

So the disparity between rich and poor

00:08:11.500 --> 00:08:13.890

is probably no greater anywhere else

00:08:13.890 --> 00:08:15.287

than right here in the

town of Southampton.

00:08:15.287 --> 00:08:18.070

And of course that

makes things complicated

00:08:18.070 --> 00:08:20.520

because you have to serve

and protect all people.

00:08:31.391 --> 00:08:34.224

(birds squawking)

00:08:35.759 --> 00:08:38.978

(engine revving)

00:08:38.978 --> 00:08:41.395

(soft music)

00:08:46.220 --> 00:08:49.710

- My family\'s been out here

since the early 1700\'s.

00:08:49.710 --> 00:08:51.760

I grew up in a farming-fishing community.

00:08:52.985 --> 00:08:54.360

You know, it\'s still a gorgeous place,

00:08:54.360 --> 00:08:55.193

don\'t get me wrong,

00:08:55.193 --> 00:08:56.893

but it\'s pretty much been bought up.

00:09:11.980 --> 00:09:14.630

20 years ago that would\'ve

been stuffed with scallops

00:09:16.350 --> 00:09:17.183

for weeks.

00:09:20.250 --> 00:09:21.793

This is called sputnik grass.

00:09:23.290 --> 00:09:24.390

It\'s kind of the only thing

00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:27.850

that every scallop larvae

has to hide in these days.

00:09:27.850 --> 00:09:28.683

It\'s heavy.

00:09:29.980 --> 00:09:32.920

With all the toxins that

are going into the bays,

00:09:32.920 --> 00:09:34.340

it makes it really difficult.

00:09:34.340 --> 00:09:38.420

You know, (laughs) God knows

what goes into these bays.

00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:41.030

In the morning you see

them spray, vector spray,

00:09:41.030 --> 00:09:42.870

for mosquito control.

00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:44.370

You\'re like, ugh.

00:09:44.370 --> 00:09:46.780

Juvenile fish are eating mosquito larvae.

00:09:46.780 --> 00:09:48.840

You know, that\'s how

the whole cycle works.

00:09:48.840 --> 00:09:50.310

A lot of the locals back in the day

00:09:50.310 --> 00:09:52.580

didn\'t really wanna build on the water.

00:09:52.580 --> 00:09:55.130

That\'s why land next to

the water was so cheap

00:09:55.130 --> 00:09:56.640

because there was too many mosquitoes.

00:09:56.640 --> 00:09:58.260

You\'d get eaten alive.

00:09:58.260 --> 00:10:00.130

You know, and now as everything is kinda

00:10:00.130 --> 00:10:03.036

changing ecologically

there\'s no mosquitoes.

00:10:03.036 --> 00:10:05.200

Well that\'s why there\'s no juvenile fish

00:10:05.200 --> 00:10:06.440

kind of making their way back up

00:10:06.440 --> 00:10:08.290

into the marshes and stuff like that.

00:10:11.970 --> 00:10:13.440

The Shinnecocks are the only ones

00:10:13.440 --> 00:10:16.093

that have respectively

kept it undeveloped.

00:10:17.959 --> 00:10:19.490

You know, if you look at the bay

00:10:19.490 --> 00:10:22.140

around where the reservation

is, it\'s gorgeous

00:10:22.140 --> 00:10:24.200

and then everywhere else

has been built up on.

00:10:24.200 --> 00:10:28.860

So, I mean, for me it has basically

00:10:28.860 --> 00:10:32.443

destroyed my livelihood,

the development on the bay.

00:10:39.730 --> 00:10:41.183

- All right, see you guys later.

00:10:46.290 --> 00:10:48.160

We\'re gonna go over to where the fish

00:10:48.160 --> 00:10:50.103

usually show up in the early season.

00:10:51.030 --> 00:10:53.060

What I do catch, I eat myself.

00:10:53.060 --> 00:10:55.730

I\'ll also give it to people

for free, free of charge

00:10:55.730 --> 00:10:57.193

up here on the reservation.

00:10:58.250 --> 00:10:59.530

I do the same thing with hunting.

00:10:59.530 --> 00:11:00.930

You know, I shoot a couple deer,

00:11:00.930 --> 00:11:02.370

I shoot a few ducks,

00:11:02.370 --> 00:11:04.920

I give them away to people

here on the reservation.

00:11:05.890 --> 00:11:06.870

People like it.

00:11:06.870 --> 00:11:08.053

My dad taught me that.

00:11:14.150 --> 00:11:16.220

One of our traditional ways

00:11:16.220 --> 00:11:17.200

at the end of a prayer

00:11:17.200 --> 00:11:18.760

or at the end of a ceremony,

00:11:18.760 --> 00:11:21.120

we say (speaking foreign language)

00:11:21.120 --> 00:11:23.103

which means all of my relations.

00:11:24.230 --> 00:11:26.040

And when you\'re saying all of my relations

00:11:26.040 --> 00:11:28.660

you\'re acknowledging the connection,

00:11:28.660 --> 00:11:30.410

not just between your immediate family,

00:11:30.410 --> 00:11:32.380

but you\'re acknowledging the connection

00:11:32.380 --> 00:11:35.040

you have to everything, all of creation,

00:11:35.040 --> 00:11:36.970

and that what you do with one thing,

00:11:36.970 --> 00:11:38.630

it affects the other thing.

00:11:38.630 --> 00:11:40.330

There\'s actually different kind of fish

00:11:40.330 --> 00:11:41.923

than there were when I was a kid.

00:11:41.923 --> 00:11:43.480

I was out there right in front

00:11:43.480 --> 00:11:44.730

of Calvin Klein\'s house, actually,

00:11:44.730 --> 00:11:45.563

and I pulled up a sand shark

00:11:45.563 --> 00:11:46.760

and the boat right next to me

00:11:46.760 --> 00:11:48.437

pulled up a sand shark too and he was like

00:11:48.437 --> 00:11:50.380

\"I\'ve never seen a sand

shark in Heady Creek!\"

00:11:50.380 --> 00:11:51.296

I was like, \"Me either!\"

00:11:51.296 --> 00:11:53.379

(laughs)

00:11:55.310 --> 00:11:57.350

Our reservation\'s a peninsula

00:11:57.350 --> 00:11:59.820

and on the east side is Heady Creek

00:11:59.820 --> 00:12:02.590

and half of Heady Creek, and just in 2015,

00:12:02.590 --> 00:12:04.450

got shut down for shellfish

00:12:04.450 --> 00:12:05.730

and that\'s just because of runoff

00:12:05.730 --> 00:12:09.203

from all the houses, the golf

course, things like that.

00:12:11.210 --> 00:12:12.790

For the most part what you see

00:12:12.790 --> 00:12:15.090

in all of the Hamptons are assets.

00:12:15.090 --> 00:12:16.850

You know, they don\'t

actually really live there

00:12:16.850 --> 00:12:17.683

for the most part.

00:12:17.683 --> 00:12:19.520

In the summertime they

come out here to vacation

00:12:19.520 --> 00:12:21.870

but for the most part, they\'re assets.

00:12:21.870 --> 00:12:23.090

If they were there year round

00:12:23.090 --> 00:12:24.790

there\'d be a lot more pollution.

00:12:24.790 --> 00:12:27.080

It is detrimental to our health here

00:12:27.080 --> 00:12:28.483

and economy on Shinnecock.

00:12:29.360 --> 00:12:30.690

You know, so our biggest thing

00:12:30.690 --> 00:12:34.273

is that we have to continue

to protect our front line.

00:12:34.273 --> 00:12:39.190

(soft music)

00:12:49.308 --> 00:12:50.404

- [Nasha] You want a clam rake?

00:12:50.404 --> 00:12:51.237

- Um, no.

00:12:52.677 --> 00:12:54.493

We\'re not doing good here.

00:12:55.410 --> 00:12:59.220

Hunting and fishing to near

extinction of everything.

00:12:59.220 --> 00:13:00.383

It happened so fast.

00:13:01.620 --> 00:13:03.520

There\'s barely any more scallops left.

00:13:06.130 --> 00:13:09.220

We had a tribal oyster

hatchery for a while

00:13:09.220 --> 00:13:12.603

but that closed down, unfortunately.

00:13:13.520 --> 00:13:16.580

So there\'s no tribal shellfish business

00:13:16.580 --> 00:13:18.163

like they do on the outside.

00:13:19.804 --> 00:13:23.090

(speaking foreign language)

00:13:23.090 --> 00:13:26.455

We\'re just back to sustenance living.

00:13:26.455 --> 00:13:28.200

You know, go out, get some clams,

00:13:28.200 --> 00:13:31.333

some mussels, scallops,

for our own supper.

00:13:32.310 --> 00:13:34.410

Fish to eat, you know, for the week or so.

00:13:37.531 --> 00:13:41.123

- Look it!

- Let\'s open our bucket.

00:13:41.123 --> 00:13:41.956

Yay!

00:13:42.864 --> 00:13:45.531

- [Girl] Now we get to eat here!

00:13:53.160 --> 00:13:58.160

- I absolutely, unequivocally

see a correlation

00:13:58.650 --> 00:14:02.450

between the overdevelopment

and especially our waterways.

00:14:02.450 --> 00:14:03.870

We are people of the shore.

00:14:03.870 --> 00:14:06.560

Our livelihood over the course of time

00:14:06.560 --> 00:14:09.340

has been derived from the waters.

00:14:09.340 --> 00:14:13.690

We, as whalers, basically

established the economy out here

00:14:13.690 --> 00:14:16.120

and selling whale oil for the street lamps

00:14:16.120 --> 00:14:17.333

and things like that.

00:14:21.850 --> 00:14:23.860

- We have to live here together.

00:14:23.860 --> 00:14:25.020

It\'s not getting any better.

00:14:25.020 --> 00:14:26.320

It\'s getting worse.

00:14:26.320 --> 00:14:27.980

The groundwater pollution,

00:14:27.980 --> 00:14:30.560

the contamination, the pesticides

00:14:30.560 --> 00:14:33.000

\'cause your lawn has to be spotless

00:14:33.000 --> 00:14:36.680

and bright green and unnatural,

00:14:36.680 --> 00:14:40.520

and the chemicals, everything

that\'s polluting this earth

00:14:40.520 --> 00:14:41.980

and we\'re drinking it and people

00:14:41.980 --> 00:14:43.810

are dying of cancer left and right.

00:14:43.810 --> 00:14:46.563

Can\'t you see it\'s got to stop?

00:14:50.150 --> 00:14:52.070

- Right here will be the tennis court,

00:14:52.070 --> 00:14:53.830

in the back is the pool,

00:14:53.830 --> 00:14:56.090

and this house will sell

for about 10 million

00:14:57.240 --> 00:14:59.690

but I\'m confident it\'ll

sell in the next 90 days.

00:15:01.512 --> 00:15:02.345

Do you speak English?

00:15:02.345 --> 00:15:03.850

- A little, yes.

00:15:03.850 --> 00:15:05.720

- I need that shut off for five minutes.

00:15:05.720 --> 00:15:07.400

- Oh, okay, okay.

- Okay, while we do something.

00:15:07.400 --> 00:15:08.380

Thanks, bud.

00:15:08.380 --> 00:15:11.140

As you see, it\'s like so wide open.

00:15:11.140 --> 00:15:13.010

This has changed with our clients

00:15:13.010 --> 00:15:15.260

who are now in their 30\'s and 40\'s

00:15:15.260 --> 00:15:17.850

and they want more modern and very open.

00:15:17.850 --> 00:15:19.050

So people pay for that

00:15:19.050 --> 00:15:20.430

and there\'s no woods.

00:15:20.430 --> 00:15:22.240

People don\'t really love the woods.

00:15:22.240 --> 00:15:23.393

They want openness.

00:15:24.240 --> 00:15:25.660

But, you know, you\'ll drive up the street

00:15:25.660 --> 00:15:28.430

and you\'ll see four of

my houses in a farm field

00:15:28.430 --> 00:15:30.423

and that gets people crazy.

00:15:32.180 --> 00:15:35.137

So, how do I defend myself against that?

00:15:35.137 --> 00:15:37.060

You know, I didn\'t buy the farm

00:15:37.060 --> 00:15:39.423

and cut it up and sell it,

00:15:40.280 --> 00:15:41.530

you know, the farmer did.

00:15:42.990 --> 00:15:44.290

- Broc, fennel,

00:15:44.290 --> 00:15:46.270

looks like forage in there.

00:15:46.270 --> 00:15:48.560

These are all perennial herbs.

00:15:48.560 --> 00:15:50.510

Cardoon over there.

00:15:50.510 --> 00:15:51.890

Edible violas.

00:15:51.890 --> 00:15:53.740

Nasturtiums.

00:15:53.740 --> 00:15:55.470

We do a lot of edible flowers.

00:15:55.470 --> 00:15:56.840

People discovered kale.

00:15:56.840 --> 00:15:59.330

Now we have about six or

eight different types of kale.

00:15:59.330 --> 00:16:01.980

- Yeah, this is a real

working farm, as you can tell.

00:16:03.060 --> 00:16:04.510

As the landscape has changed,

00:16:04.510 --> 00:16:06.450

we\'ve had to evolve.

00:16:06.450 --> 00:16:08.050

And it\'s constant.

00:16:08.050 --> 00:16:10.070

Nettles, 12.99 a pound.

00:16:10.070 --> 00:16:13.430

The family farm has been

here since the 1600\'s

00:16:13.430 --> 00:16:16.770

and we are the 11th generation.

00:16:16.770 --> 00:16:21.067

We were growing up in a very

sweet provincial little town

00:16:21.067 --> 00:16:23.290

and there was so much land.

00:16:23.290 --> 00:16:24.925

I mean, I...

00:16:24.925 --> 00:16:27.500

It\'s really amazing what\'s happened

00:16:27.500 --> 00:16:29.245

in a short amount of time

00:16:29.245 --> 00:16:30.670

with the waters being polluted

00:16:30.670 --> 00:16:32.480

and the overbuilding.

00:16:32.480 --> 00:16:34.750

- Yeah, even in the past 10, 15 years

00:16:34.750 --> 00:16:36.610

a lot of acreage that we used to rent

00:16:36.610 --> 00:16:40.223

from family members, now

that\'s all gone and developed.

00:16:41.130 --> 00:16:43.390

- It\'s a lot easier to

sell an acre of land

00:16:43.390 --> 00:16:44.403

for half a million dollars

00:16:44.403 --> 00:16:49.403

than it is to struggle and

work 50, 60 hours a week.

00:16:50.720 --> 00:16:55.504

(soft music)

00:17:01.060 --> 00:17:03.140

- Since 1640 there were all these

00:17:03.140 --> 00:17:06.000

different disputes about land.

00:17:06.000 --> 00:17:08.920

People challenging whether

the land was theirs,

00:17:08.920 --> 00:17:11.710

whether they had the right to graze there.

00:17:11.710 --> 00:17:14.500

The town of Southampton

approached the tribe

00:17:14.500 --> 00:17:16.367

and said \"Okay, this is how we\'re going

00:17:16.367 --> 00:17:17.737

\"to try to resolve this.

00:17:17.737 --> 00:17:22.357

\"We will give to the tribe

a lease for 1,000 years.\"

00:17:24.030 --> 00:17:28.000

And that includes the lands

for where we live now,

00:17:28.000 --> 00:17:31.570

Shinnecock Neck, the Shinnecock Hills.

00:17:31.570 --> 00:17:33.910

We were able to hold this lease

00:17:33.910 --> 00:17:35.920

and then the tribe would sublease

00:17:35.920 --> 00:17:38.000

to farmers and other people

00:17:38.000 --> 00:17:40.350

and still be able to use our own land.

00:17:40.350 --> 00:17:44.300

That\'s how we were able to get

a lot of our basic needs met.

00:17:44.300 --> 00:17:48.100

- We were given a lease

for 3,000 plus acres.

00:17:48.100 --> 00:17:51.300

That was whittled away,

whittled away, whittled away

00:17:51.300 --> 00:17:52.970

until 1859.

00:17:52.970 --> 00:17:56.330

1859, the robber barons,

the railroad people,

00:17:56.330 --> 00:17:58.200

wanted to build the railroad line

00:17:58.200 --> 00:18:00.510

from Manhattan out to Montauk

00:18:00.510 --> 00:18:05.510

and in blatant disregard

for the Non-intercourse Act,

00:18:06.220 --> 00:18:10.750

which said that no state,

no town, no village,

00:18:10.750 --> 00:18:14.180

no farmer could take land from an Indian

00:18:14.180 --> 00:18:17.130

or an Indian tribe without

an act of Congress.

00:18:17.130 --> 00:18:19.850

Well New York state,

they had 20 signatures

00:18:19.850 --> 00:18:22.690

supposedly giving the land to the state.

00:18:22.690 --> 00:18:26.870

Well 10 of those signatures

were people that were dead.

00:18:26.870 --> 00:18:29.770

They had gone and gotten

names off of headstones.

00:18:29.770 --> 00:18:32.380

The other 10 were not Shinnecock.

00:18:32.380 --> 00:18:34.650

This is what they put before the judge,

00:18:34.650 --> 00:18:37.280

they got the land, and our people,

00:18:37.280 --> 00:18:40.680

from that next day when

we found out about it,

00:18:40.680 --> 00:18:43.610

proceeded to fight for it.

00:18:43.610 --> 00:18:47.460

But we, as Indian people,

were not considered citizens,

00:18:47.460 --> 00:18:50.973

so they would not allow us

to take this into court.

00:18:51.930 --> 00:18:53.520

This land was stolen from us.

00:18:53.520 --> 00:18:57.703

Flat-out, no questions,

hands down, stolen.

00:19:00.090 --> 00:19:02.030

Now what sits on the acreage

00:19:02.030 --> 00:19:03.050

is some of the most

00:19:03.050 --> 00:19:06.560

prestigious golf courses in the world.

00:19:06.560 --> 00:19:08.967

You have a national golf course.

00:19:08.967 --> 00:19:11.390

You have a brand new one,

Sebonack Golf Course.

00:19:11.390 --> 00:19:15.800

You have Shinnecock Hills which

will be hosting the US Open.

00:19:15.800 --> 00:19:18.520

And you have a multitude of

multi-million dollar homes

00:19:18.520 --> 00:19:22.313

that sit in what was once

our sacred Shinnecock Hills.

00:19:30.400 --> 00:19:33.390

- Property under video surveillance.

00:19:33.390 --> 00:19:36.410

This is the Shinnecock Hills Golf Course.

00:19:36.410 --> 00:19:39.390

This was, this is a sacred place to us

00:19:39.390 --> 00:19:41.560

and it was a long time ago

00:19:41.560 --> 00:19:42.713

and it still is.

00:19:43.740 --> 00:19:47.160

We can come here but still

we\'re on the outside.

00:19:47.160 --> 00:19:48.780

We\'re not allowed in here.

00:19:48.780 --> 00:19:53.780

We\'re not allowed any

access to our sacred sites.

00:19:54.500 --> 00:19:57.680

They use our name for whatever they want.

00:19:57.680 --> 00:20:01.100

Their logo is a native

chief with a headdress on.

00:20:01.100 --> 00:20:05.160

It\'s the in your face kind of boldness.

00:20:05.160 --> 00:20:08.170

We know we have still to this day

00:20:09.180 --> 00:20:13.913

ancestors buried in this golf course.

00:20:14.760 --> 00:20:17.700

Buried with respect and ceremony

00:20:17.700 --> 00:20:19.683

and love and honor.

00:20:21.090 --> 00:20:26.090

Shinnecock men were hired to

help construct the golf course.

00:20:26.220 --> 00:20:28.230

Stories handed down to us say

00:20:28.230 --> 00:20:30.200

that they witnessed hundreds and hundreds

00:20:30.200 --> 00:20:33.650

of the ancestor\'s bones being desecrated

00:20:33.650 --> 00:20:35.120

during this construction.

00:20:35.120 --> 00:20:37.150

They couldn\'t do anything about it.

00:20:37.150 --> 00:20:39.950

And to host the U.S Golf Open here,

00:20:39.950 --> 00:20:41.970

it\'s just a slap in the face.

00:20:41.970 --> 00:20:43.550

- [Employee] What are you guys doing?

00:20:43.550 --> 00:20:45.395

- [Woman] We\'re making a documentary.

00:20:45.395 --> 00:20:46.946

- Okay well, I got a call about

00:20:46.946 --> 00:20:49.590

a suspicious vehicle here, so.

00:20:49.590 --> 00:20:51.310

- We\'re not trespassing.

00:20:51.310 --> 00:20:53.530

This is none of your business

right now, so goodbye.

00:20:53.530 --> 00:20:54.363

- Actually it is.

- Goodbye, no it isn\'t.

00:20:54.363 --> 00:20:55.196

- [Employee] I\'m an

employee of the golf club.

00:20:55.196 --> 00:20:56.890

- This is public property, goodbye,

00:20:56.890 --> 00:20:58.240

and I\'m a Shinnecock Indian.

00:20:58.240 --> 00:20:59.389

So leave us alone, goodbye.

- I don\'t care about

00:20:59.389 --> 00:21:00.222

that at all.

00:21:00.222 --> 00:21:01.055

- I don\'t care who you are either.

00:21:01.055 --> 00:21:02.780

We\'re on public property, leave us alone.

00:21:02.780 --> 00:21:03.613

Leave us alone.

00:21:03.613 --> 00:21:04.690

- [Employee] You\'re

not on public property.

00:21:04.690 --> 00:21:05.955

- This is, are you kidding me?

00:21:05.955 --> 00:21:07.040

- Want me to call the police?

00:21:07.040 --> 00:21:08.767

- Sure, go right ahead.

- Okay, ma\'am.

00:21:08.767 --> 00:21:10.440

- I\'m not even on the golf course.

00:21:10.440 --> 00:21:12.005

I\'m on the doggone shoulder

00:21:12.005 --> 00:21:13.863

and already this guy is harassing me.

00:21:16.950 --> 00:21:19.910

Well that\'s how the

Parrish Pond fight started.

00:21:19.910 --> 00:21:21.340

We were on the shoulder of the road

00:21:21.340 --> 00:21:23.650

having our peaceful protest

00:21:23.650 --> 00:21:25.890

and the New York State Police showed up

00:21:26.740 --> 00:21:28.690

with a chip on their shoulder.

00:21:28.690 --> 00:21:30.679

Someone told them that

there was a bunch of Indians

00:21:30.679 --> 00:21:32.880

on the side of the road protesting

00:21:32.880 --> 00:21:35.230

the desecration of the land.

00:21:35.230 --> 00:21:36.450

We were well within our rights

00:21:36.450 --> 00:21:38.320

where we were standing.

00:21:38.320 --> 00:21:42.020

This is the Parrish Pond development.

00:21:42.020 --> 00:21:45.230

62 acres of beautiful, pristine land

00:21:45.230 --> 00:21:48.623

with some of the last of

the marine plant life,

00:21:49.500 --> 00:21:50.893

Heathland they call it.

00:21:53.670 --> 00:21:54.510

It\'s gone.

00:21:54.510 --> 00:21:57.003

It\'s now someone\'s lawn.

00:21:59.020 --> 00:22:00.193

It\'s gone forever.

00:22:02.392 --> 00:22:04.256

We are protecting our sovereign territory.

00:22:04.256 --> 00:22:05.497

- [Man] You\'re talking about our land.

00:22:05.497 --> 00:22:06.800

- Where\'s that not one more acre sign?

00:22:06.800 --> 00:22:07.633

Can you read that?

00:22:07.633 --> 00:22:09.080

I hope everybody here can read

00:22:09.080 --> 00:22:10.570

\'cause that\'s what we\'re here for.

00:22:10.570 --> 00:22:11.883

Not one more acre.

00:22:12.770 --> 00:22:14.300

Not one more acre.

00:22:15.887 --> 00:22:17.640

The state police were just hollering

00:22:17.640 --> 00:22:18.943

and cursing at us.

00:22:19.990 --> 00:22:20.990

One in particular,

00:22:20.990 --> 00:22:23.893

after the bulldozers

started up their engines,

00:22:26.070 --> 00:22:28.930

he came from behind with all his might

00:22:28.930 --> 00:22:32.033

and pushed me into the middle of the road.

00:22:40.620 --> 00:22:42.970

We know that bones were dug up here

00:22:42.970 --> 00:22:45.170

and construction workers were instructed

00:22:45.170 --> 00:22:46.633

to put them in the dumpster.

00:22:49.650 --> 00:22:52.870

- When we ride through

the Shinnecock Hills,

00:22:52.870 --> 00:22:57.400

and you see what we consider

the destruction of our land,

00:22:57.400 --> 00:22:59.040

you know, you hear about the Sioux

00:22:59.040 --> 00:23:02.020

and their famed Black Hills,

00:23:02.020 --> 00:23:03.730

our Shinnecock Hills here

00:23:03.730 --> 00:23:07.490

held the same meaning,

the same historic value

00:23:07.490 --> 00:23:10.900

that any of these other

tribes around the country

00:23:10.900 --> 00:23:13.150

have held with their land.

00:23:13.150 --> 00:23:15.560

We\'ve had several digs

up in the hills there

00:23:15.560 --> 00:23:19.290

that have traced our lineage in this area

00:23:19.290 --> 00:23:21.053

back over 10,000 years.

00:23:22.690 --> 00:23:26.960

- Our ancestors would bury

people on the hilltops.

00:23:26.960 --> 00:23:28.740

The villages that we would live on

00:23:28.740 --> 00:23:32.500

would be on the east

side where the sun rises

00:23:32.500 --> 00:23:36.390

and then the burials

would be all facing west

00:23:36.390 --> 00:23:39.160

and so that\'s so the sunset can bring them

00:23:39.160 --> 00:23:40.673

into the spirit world.

00:23:57.331 --> 00:24:02.139

(train rattling)

00:24:12.840 --> 00:24:14.754

- Good morning, everybody.

00:24:14.754 --> 00:24:17.610

Did you guys have a good

Memorial Day weekend?

00:24:17.610 --> 00:24:19.763

Ruthie and I, we have a special guest here

00:24:19.763 --> 00:24:21.090

with us today.

00:24:21.090 --> 00:24:23.273

Our town supervisor, Jay

Schneiderman is here.

00:24:23.273 --> 00:24:25.510

(crowd applauding)

00:24:25.510 --> 00:24:26.343

- Thank you.

00:24:26.343 --> 00:24:28.740

It\'s an honor for me to

serve as your supervisor.

00:24:28.740 --> 00:24:30.388

The town is in great shape.

00:24:30.388 --> 00:24:32.410

We continue to work really hard

00:24:32.410 --> 00:24:35.520

on protecting drinking

water and surface waters

00:24:35.520 --> 00:24:39.520

and open space, keeping taxes

low which I know is important.

00:24:39.520 --> 00:24:41.640

We have the U.S. Open coming

00:24:41.640 --> 00:24:44.800

and you know, the big

USGA golf tournament,

00:24:44.800 --> 00:24:47.320

that is coming next week.

00:24:47.320 --> 00:24:49.450

It brings a lot of money to the economy

00:24:49.450 --> 00:24:50.899

and that\'s a good thing.

00:24:50.899 --> 00:24:52.610

- [Citizen] My question\'s about taxes.

00:24:52.610 --> 00:24:53.443

- [Jay] Sure.

00:24:53.443 --> 00:24:55.980

- Taxes really have become a problem.

00:24:55.980 --> 00:24:57.240

Are you concerned about that?

00:24:57.240 --> 00:24:59.850

- So I realize a lot of

you pay property taxes

00:24:59.850 --> 00:25:02.550

and property values are

going up in general.

00:25:02.550 --> 00:25:04.810

And I know most of you

are on fixed incomes.

00:25:04.810 --> 00:25:08.300

The high cost of land complicates

a lot of things out here

00:25:08.300 --> 00:25:09.970

and it acts as a filter.

00:25:09.970 --> 00:25:11.930

So a lot of people who may be

00:25:11.930 --> 00:25:13.410

third, fourth, fifth generation

00:25:13.410 --> 00:25:14.963

kinda grew up out here,

00:25:16.090 --> 00:25:18.430

they see the cost of living go up

00:25:18.430 --> 00:25:20.830

but their property values

are going through the roof.

00:25:20.830 --> 00:25:23.550

Their taxes are going higher and higher.

00:25:23.550 --> 00:25:24.940

They end up selling those houses

00:25:24.940 --> 00:25:27.600

and then that house will become

00:25:27.600 --> 00:25:29.510

probably a second home

00:25:29.510 --> 00:25:32.460

and somebody will have to

service that second home

00:25:32.460 --> 00:25:35.120

to take care of the landscaping

00:25:35.120 --> 00:25:38.260

or fix the boiler or mow the lawn.

00:25:38.260 --> 00:25:39.750

That person probably isn\'t gonna be able

00:25:39.750 --> 00:25:41.180

to live in the community.

00:25:41.180 --> 00:25:44.410

So a lot more workers are commuting in

00:25:44.410 --> 00:25:45.457

from further and further away

00:25:45.457 --> 00:25:48.360

and you see that in the mornings between,

00:25:48.360 --> 00:25:50.560

say 6:00 o\'clock and 9:00 o\'clock.

00:25:50.560 --> 00:25:54.430

The traffic eastbound is unbelievable.

00:25:54.430 --> 00:25:56.660

So we\'re creating a demand for labor

00:25:56.660 --> 00:25:58.750

that can\'t live in this community.

00:25:58.750 --> 00:26:00.340

- [Reporter] Southampton

town officials say

00:26:00.340 --> 00:26:02.700

the most horrifying violations they found

00:26:02.700 --> 00:26:04.910

at the Bel-Aire Cove Motel.

00:26:04.910 --> 00:26:06.450

Town code officers this week

00:26:06.450 --> 00:26:10.930

issued 215 code violations

against 28 landlords.

00:26:10.930 --> 00:26:13.310

Officials say they found 17 people

00:26:13.310 --> 00:26:16.022

living in this four bedroom house.

00:26:16.022 --> 00:26:18.439

(soft music)

00:26:21.410 --> 00:26:22.970

- A lot of people are struggling.

00:26:22.970 --> 00:26:27.627

If a three bedroom house

cost you, I don\'t know,

00:26:27.627 --> 00:26:31.710

$3,000 a month and you\'re only making,

00:26:31.710 --> 00:26:33.943

you know, $15 an hour,

00:26:35.360 --> 00:26:39.800

and they\'re only letting

you work 25 hours a week

00:26:39.800 --> 00:26:42.593

because they don\'t wanna

give you insurance,

00:26:43.500 --> 00:26:45.640

we have people that

don\'t have places to live

00:26:45.640 --> 00:26:48.110

that are sleeping out in the woods

00:26:48.110 --> 00:26:50.910

or have making little shacks

for themselves to live

00:26:50.910 --> 00:26:53.080

because they\'re poor and they\'re homeless.

00:26:53.080 --> 00:26:53.913

People hear that.

00:26:53.913 --> 00:26:55.327

They\'re like \"Oh, you\'re in the Hamptons.

00:26:55.327 --> 00:26:56.427

\"What are you talking about?

00:26:56.427 --> 00:26:57.747

\"Are you kidding me?

00:26:57.747 --> 00:26:59.520

\"You\'re in the Hamptons.\"

00:26:59.520 --> 00:27:02.950

- It\'s a kind of classic

town gown in the Hamptons.

00:27:02.950 --> 00:27:04.590

The professional middle class

00:27:04.590 --> 00:27:06.400

is so far from the elite

00:27:06.400 --> 00:27:09.000

and there is such an

antagonism towards the elite.

00:27:09.000 --> 00:27:11.040

You could feel that on a visceral level.

00:27:11.040 --> 00:27:15.640

On the other hand, the whole

economy is based on this elite.

00:27:15.640 --> 00:27:18.590

And so it\'s really hard not to kind of

00:27:18.590 --> 00:27:21.570

continue to market and cater to this elite

00:27:21.570 --> 00:27:23.743

at the same time that you resent them.

00:27:24.910 --> 00:27:28.850

I think the Hamptons represents

a historical microcosm

00:27:28.850 --> 00:27:30.747

of the class struggle

here in the United States

00:27:30.747 --> 00:27:33.310

and in many cases, around the world

00:27:33.310 --> 00:27:36.400

because it begins when Native Americans

00:27:36.400 --> 00:27:38.270

who had lived here on the land

00:27:38.270 --> 00:27:40.410

have that land taken away from them

00:27:40.410 --> 00:27:41.600

and the only thing left

00:27:41.600 --> 00:27:42.960

is really for them to become

00:27:42.960 --> 00:27:45.363

the initial working class

here in the Hamptons.

00:27:47.210 --> 00:27:49.490

- Did you have fun on the playground?

00:27:49.490 --> 00:27:51.940

Did you go to the

playground or to the beach?

00:27:51.940 --> 00:27:53.107

- To the park.

00:27:53.107 --> 00:27:54.350

- Okay.

00:27:54.350 --> 00:27:56.710

One child sleeps on that couch.

00:27:56.710 --> 00:27:57.850

Two sleep on this couch.

00:27:57.850 --> 00:27:59.470

I sleep on that bed.

00:27:59.470 --> 00:28:02.450

And when another grandson comes over

00:28:02.450 --> 00:28:03.940

he sleeps like right here.

00:28:03.940 --> 00:28:06.520

He\'ll put the pillows down and sleep here.

00:28:06.520 --> 00:28:10.320

And then Nasha and her

daughter sleep in one bedroom

00:28:10.320 --> 00:28:12.890

and my mother sleeps in that bedroom.

00:28:12.890 --> 00:28:15.720

So, we have to take care of each other.

00:28:15.720 --> 00:28:18.873

The housing situation doesn\'t

get any better around here.

00:28:20.550 --> 00:28:23.673

And I mean, the oppression runs deep.

00:28:26.840 --> 00:28:28.380

- Every member of the Shinnecock Nation

00:28:28.380 --> 00:28:31.320

is a member of the town of Southampton

00:28:31.320 --> 00:28:33.140

and so they\'re entitled to everything

00:28:33.140 --> 00:28:35.700

that any town resident would have.

00:28:35.700 --> 00:28:37.140

They certainly vote,

00:28:37.140 --> 00:28:40.040

they get permits to park on the beaches,

00:28:40.040 --> 00:28:42.180

they use all town facilities.

00:28:42.180 --> 00:28:43.760

There are tremendous things

00:28:43.760 --> 00:28:45.990

that members of the nation

can take advantage of

00:28:45.990 --> 00:28:48.150

without paying any property taxes.

00:28:48.150 --> 00:28:50.910

But we do have high value properties

00:28:50.910 --> 00:28:51.900

that pay high taxes

00:28:51.900 --> 00:28:53.480

that provide services.

00:28:53.480 --> 00:28:56.730

Youth services, transportation services,

00:28:56.730 --> 00:28:58.320

park services, roads.

00:28:58.320 --> 00:28:59.680

And the Shinnecock Nation,

00:28:59.680 --> 00:29:01.820

they benefit from all of those things.

00:29:01.820 --> 00:29:03.580

The same things that I

can take advantage of

00:29:03.580 --> 00:29:05.650

and you know, I pay property taxes.

00:29:05.650 --> 00:29:09.430

We\'re obviously in a very

strong fiscal position.

00:29:09.430 --> 00:29:12.550

We\'re improving our roads,

we\'re fixing drainage problems,

00:29:12.550 --> 00:29:14.740

we\'re addressing infrastructure,

00:29:14.740 --> 00:29:17.870

we\'re improving our parks

that everybody enjoys.

00:29:17.870 --> 00:29:19.910

What happens when you do that?

00:29:19.910 --> 00:29:22.950

People want to live in

a community like that.

00:29:22.950 --> 00:29:25.510

- What we\'ve done is

tremendous for the town.

00:29:25.510 --> 00:29:27.450

400 homes we\'ve built

00:29:27.450 --> 00:29:32.080

and the average tax bill\'s

gotta be $30,000 on my homes.

00:29:32.080 --> 00:29:33.870

It\'s really helped keep up

00:29:33.870 --> 00:29:35.450

with the ever growing budget.

00:29:35.450 --> 00:29:38.540

You know, the town needs the

development to keep going.

00:29:38.540 --> 00:29:40.020

They\'ll never say that

00:29:40.020 --> 00:29:42.472

but what would they do without it?

00:29:42.472 --> 00:29:44.972

(heavy music)

00:29:51.770 --> 00:29:56.650

- The Hamptons as a place

of paradise and respite

00:29:56.650 --> 00:29:59.590

was something that Walt

Whitman wrote about

00:29:59.590 --> 00:30:01.930

and inspired a whole generation of artists

00:30:01.930 --> 00:30:03.423

to leave New York to go out.

00:30:04.560 --> 00:30:07.320

It became a place that symbolized nature.

00:30:07.320 --> 00:30:10.320

It\'s symbolized this authenticity.

00:30:10.320 --> 00:30:15.320

As the bohemian pioneers do in

all forms of gentrification,

00:30:15.580 --> 00:30:18.640

the artists brought out

the very rich people

00:30:18.640 --> 00:30:21.140

who saw this place for its natural beauty

00:30:21.140 --> 00:30:24.023

but also as a place that they

could put their mark on it.

00:30:24.960 --> 00:30:26.530

Very wealthy people from New York City

00:30:26.530 --> 00:30:30.030

went out and built these

huge summer cottages

00:30:30.030 --> 00:30:31.980

and it became kind of the place

00:30:31.980 --> 00:30:34.180

for the rich and famous to go.

00:30:34.180 --> 00:30:37.560

On the one hand,

celebrating its naturalness

00:30:37.560 --> 00:30:40.150

but also bringing in electric lights

00:30:40.150 --> 00:30:41.830

and bringing in the golf clubs

00:30:41.830 --> 00:30:43.850

and bringing in all

the different trappings

00:30:43.850 --> 00:30:46.093

of their New York high society.

00:30:52.880 --> 00:30:54.960

- Hi, welcome back to \"Talk of the Town\".

00:30:54.960 --> 00:30:56.190

I\'m your host Jay Schneiderman

00:30:56.190 --> 00:30:58.400

and we are talking about the U.S. Open,

00:30:58.400 --> 00:31:00.600

the 118th U.S. Open.

00:31:00.600 --> 00:31:04.460

You have been here for two

years planning this event.

00:31:04.460 --> 00:31:05.950

- [Man] We\'ve been in

the community for a while

00:31:05.950 --> 00:31:07.073

but now it\'s real.

00:31:07.073 --> 00:31:10.050

- Well we certainly like

having you guys here.

00:31:10.050 --> 00:31:11.340

We try at the town level

00:31:11.340 --> 00:31:13.180

to be as accommodating as we can

00:31:13.180 --> 00:31:15.410

and we recognize over $100 million

00:31:16.246 --> 00:31:18.313

in economic flow into the community.

00:31:20.340 --> 00:31:22.860

- Despite the bumper to bumper traffic,

00:31:22.860 --> 00:31:24.010

and the hassle of getting

00:31:24.010 --> 00:31:26.990

to one of golf\'s premier

tournaments played right here

00:31:26.990 --> 00:31:30.000

at Shinnecock Hills Golf

Course in Southampton,

00:31:30.000 --> 00:31:32.860

it\'s estimated about 30,000 spectators

00:31:32.860 --> 00:31:34.450

will attend the week long event,

00:31:34.450 --> 00:31:37.230

helping business boom in the area.

00:31:37.230 --> 00:31:39.670

Including here at Melrose Pizza

00:31:39.670 --> 00:31:41.820

where pies are flying out the door.

00:31:41.820 --> 00:31:44.190

And they are certainly

happy to get a piece

00:31:44.190 --> 00:31:47.720

of the U.S. Open pie.

00:31:47.720 --> 00:31:50.220

- You guys sat right at the table with us

00:31:50.220 --> 00:31:51.430

in that last meeting

00:31:51.430 --> 00:31:53.570

and I feel personally that you misled us.

00:31:53.570 --> 00:31:55.550

So, as far as I\'m concerned,

00:31:55.550 --> 00:31:56.770

you could\'ve mentioned that then

00:31:56.770 --> 00:31:59.570

and said well we really have

no need for overflow parking

00:31:59.570 --> 00:32:01.470

when Sage and Williams said to you

00:32:01.470 --> 00:32:02.897

all the people coming from the east

00:32:02.897 --> 00:32:04.900

could be parked on the res.

00:32:04.900 --> 00:32:06.120

You never mentioned that you had

00:32:06.120 --> 00:32:08.390

already established parking east.

00:32:08.390 --> 00:32:10.497

So, you know, you can sit there

00:32:10.497 --> 00:32:11.840

and try to spin it because

00:32:11.840 --> 00:32:13.870

that\'s what you do as a media person,

00:32:13.870 --> 00:32:15.930

but we still have to answer to the people

00:32:15.930 --> 00:32:18.360

and the people right

now didn\'t even want us

00:32:18.360 --> 00:32:20.330

to continue any negotiations.

00:32:20.330 --> 00:32:22.832

That was the sentiment

in the meeting Wednesday.

00:32:22.832 --> 00:32:24.410

(audience applauding)

00:32:24.410 --> 00:32:26.050

- [Golfer] Hey Phil, hit

it in the holes, baby.

00:32:26.050 --> 00:32:26.883

Yeah, baby!

00:32:27.870 --> 00:32:29.900

- Don\'t even continue the negotiations.

00:32:29.900 --> 00:32:32.903

Like, let\'s just go out there and protest.

00:32:32.903 --> 00:32:33.749

(tribal percussion music)

00:32:33.749 --> 00:32:38.082

(woman singing in foreign language)

00:33:02.359 --> 00:33:07.359

(car horn honks)

(woman vociferating)

00:33:07.527 --> 00:33:08.447

- Hi, Rebecca.

00:33:08.447 --> 00:33:09.672

- Hi, how are you?

00:33:09.672 --> 00:33:13.409

We\'ll be here probably from at

least 8:00 to 5:00 everyday.

00:33:13.409 --> 00:33:14.670

- Okay.

- Yeah.

00:33:14.670 --> 00:33:17.690

He said if we need

anything just let him know.

00:33:17.690 --> 00:33:18.790

We need our land back.

00:33:20.080 --> 00:33:21.410

- You know, they\'re sitting on

00:33:21.410 --> 00:33:24.670

one of the most valuable

pieces of land in the country

00:33:24.670 --> 00:33:27.713

and they could generate

income from that land.

00:33:28.570 --> 00:33:33.570

Like they could all be

millionaires, literally.

00:33:33.840 --> 00:33:36.180

But they can\'t seem to get behind

00:33:36.180 --> 00:33:38.853

any one idea and stick

with it for very long.

00:33:39.750 --> 00:33:41.320

I don\'t know what\'s the right

00:33:41.320 --> 00:33:45.150

economic development

direction for the Shinnecocks.

00:33:45.150 --> 00:33:46.633

It\'s really up to them.

00:33:49.770 --> 00:33:51.493

But they have opportunities.

00:33:53.980 --> 00:33:55.880

The town is not standing in their way.

00:33:57.120 --> 00:33:59.600

- [Reporter] It\'s the

multi-million dollar question,

00:33:59.600 --> 00:34:01.530

where will the Shinnecock Indians

00:34:01.530 --> 00:34:03.010

want to build their casino

00:34:03.010 --> 00:34:04.780

now that they\'ve cleared a big hurdle

00:34:04.780 --> 00:34:07.337

in getting federal recognition as a tribe?

00:34:07.337 --> 00:34:09.180

- There was a tribe in Connecticut

00:34:09.180 --> 00:34:12.520

that owned one of the largest

casinos in the country.

00:34:12.520 --> 00:34:14.170

They excelled.

00:34:14.170 --> 00:34:17.330

They went by us like

we were standing still

00:34:17.330 --> 00:34:22.330

and in terms of creating

economic development.

00:34:22.510 --> 00:34:24.510

When we started the gaming

00:34:24.510 --> 00:34:28.023

there was a lot of hope in our community.

00:34:29.397 --> 00:34:30.230

As soon as we did that

00:34:30.230 --> 00:34:32.110

we became public enemy number one.

00:34:32.110 --> 00:34:33.760

- I\'ve been living here 43 years.

00:34:33.760 --> 00:34:35.320

I have no desire to have that around here.

00:34:35.320 --> 00:34:36.900

- The island\'s narrow.

00:34:36.900 --> 00:34:39.280

We have traffic problems as it is.

00:34:39.280 --> 00:34:43.040

- Certainly, revenues from

a casino could be quite high

00:34:43.040 --> 00:34:44.964

but the community does not want to see

00:34:44.964 --> 00:34:48.100

a gambling facility out on the east end.

00:34:48.100 --> 00:34:50.520

A lot of people had

concerns about the traffic

00:34:50.520 --> 00:34:54.300

and the problems that are

sometimes associated with gaming.

00:34:54.300 --> 00:34:55.583

- It\'s gonna cause traffic.

00:34:55.583 --> 00:34:57.900

Have you been out there on 27 lately

00:34:57.900 --> 00:34:59.840

to understand the traffic out there?

00:34:59.840 --> 00:35:01.210

We didn\'t create that.

00:35:01.210 --> 00:35:02.043

You did.

00:35:03.720 --> 00:35:06.210

We were going to start a small facility.

00:35:06.210 --> 00:35:07.310

We weren\'t going to go into

00:35:07.310 --> 00:35:11.710

the big billion dollar

facilities or anything like that.

00:35:11.710 --> 00:35:13.080

We went through that whole year

00:35:13.080 --> 00:35:14.890

and it was really a nightmare.

00:35:14.890 --> 00:35:16.777

The developer backed away

00:35:16.777 --> 00:35:18.800

and the whole thing just fell apart.

00:35:18.800 --> 00:35:20.680

Literally, it fell apart.

00:35:20.680 --> 00:35:23.630

While we were good neighbors

everything was okay.

00:35:23.630 --> 00:35:25.160

You know, as long as you Indians

00:35:25.160 --> 00:35:27.880

stay up on the reservation

and in your place,

00:35:27.880 --> 00:35:29.983

you know, we\'re fine having you here.

00:35:31.830 --> 00:35:33.910

- I\'m not really sure what else

00:35:33.910 --> 00:35:36.690

the town can do for members of the nation

00:35:36.690 --> 00:35:38.320

but I think that they could improve

00:35:38.320 --> 00:35:40.743

their economic situation in a lot of ways

00:35:40.743 --> 00:35:43.800

and I\'d love to work

with the Tribal Council

00:35:43.800 --> 00:35:46.470

moving an idea forward as long as it\'s one

00:35:46.470 --> 00:35:51.130

that is, you know, really

supports the community,

00:35:51.130 --> 00:35:54.000

it\'s not gonna be a

problem for the community.

00:35:54.000 --> 00:35:57.150

- The Hamptons itself has become a brand.

00:35:57.150 --> 00:35:59.160

It\'s become a commodity.

00:35:59.160 --> 00:36:00.450

And one of the things

00:36:00.450 --> 00:36:02.550

that\'s buttress the image of the Hamptons

00:36:02.550 --> 00:36:04.780

as the land of the rich and famous

00:36:04.780 --> 00:36:07.630

is the marketing to the rich and famous.

00:36:07.630 --> 00:36:10.880

That makes it even harder for

people who are struggling.

00:36:10.880 --> 00:36:12.920

That makes it even harder for the people

00:36:12.920 --> 00:36:14.880

who are in the backroom doing the dishes

00:36:14.880 --> 00:36:17.400

or the people who are

serving and being ignored

00:36:17.400 --> 00:36:19.420

or the people who are cleaning the streets

00:36:19.420 --> 00:36:20.870

or the people who are in places

00:36:20.870 --> 00:36:22.950

like the Shinnecock Reservation

00:36:22.950 --> 00:36:27.480

where you essentially have

whatever cultural capitol

00:36:27.480 --> 00:36:30.150

having, quote unquote, \"Real Indians\"

00:36:30.150 --> 00:36:33.006

gives to a location but

without any knowledge

00:36:33.006 --> 00:36:34.780

of the history struggle

00:36:34.780 --> 00:36:37.295

and what those different

locations actually mean.

00:36:37.295 --> 00:36:42.287

(soft music)

00:37:09.820 --> 00:37:13.549

- We\'ve seen more Porches

and Mercedes and--

00:37:13.549 --> 00:37:14.764

(car horn honks)

00:37:14.764 --> 00:37:16.380

Whoo!

00:37:16.380 --> 00:37:17.547

Thanks friend!

00:37:18.482 --> 00:37:19.526

- Hi, how you doing?

00:37:19.526 --> 00:37:20.773

- Good.

- All right, and you?

00:37:20.773 --> 00:37:21.651

- I\'m well.

00:37:21.651 --> 00:37:25.490

So I saw the signs and I wanted

to see what was going on.

00:37:25.490 --> 00:37:30.490

So there are remains that are just--

00:37:31.260 --> 00:37:33.920

- Our ancestors are still buried there.

00:37:33.920 --> 00:37:35.140

- What do you think should be done

00:37:35.140 --> 00:37:36.730

for them to right a wrong?

00:37:36.730 --> 00:37:38.290

Like what do you think?

00:37:38.290 --> 00:37:39.123

- [Woman] Really?

00:37:39.123 --> 00:37:40.560

Give us our land back.

00:37:40.560 --> 00:37:43.060

- Yeah, you want the whole course back.

00:37:43.060 --> 00:37:44.562

- It would be nice if

we got our whole 360--

00:37:44.562 --> 00:37:45.395

- That would be nice.

00:37:45.395 --> 00:37:47.245

I don\'t think that that

actually will happen.

00:37:47.245 --> 00:37:49.190

- They can start with the

reconstruction of the graves

00:37:49.190 --> 00:37:53.160

so that they don\'t play golf

on the graves of our ancestors.

00:37:53.160 --> 00:37:56.180

- And at least acknowledgment

to Shinnecock, the people.

00:37:56.180 --> 00:37:58.060

Not Shinnecock the golf course.

00:37:58.060 --> 00:37:58.893

- No, I know.

00:37:58.893 --> 00:38:00.300

I was really curious because I know

00:38:00.300 --> 00:38:03.930

there\'s millions and millions

of dollars being made.

00:38:03.930 --> 00:38:05.280

Like how can you right

00:38:05.280 --> 00:38:08.823

or how would you want the

right, the wrong to be--

00:38:08.823 --> 00:38:10.070

- [Woman] I just told you.

00:38:10.070 --> 00:38:11.060

- Yeah to get back the land.

00:38:11.060 --> 00:38:12.555

- [Woman] I just told

you, give back our land.

00:38:12.555 --> 00:38:13.950

- Right, they probably won\'t.

- That\'s all.

00:38:13.950 --> 00:38:16.220

- Why is it fair to continue on

00:38:16.220 --> 00:38:18.910

committing this crime of stolen property?

00:38:18.910 --> 00:38:21.200

Just because you stole it

a hundred and so years ago

00:38:21.200 --> 00:38:23.720

doesn\'t mean the crime goes away.

00:38:23.720 --> 00:38:27.300

You take our land, you

desecrate our graves,

00:38:27.300 --> 00:38:29.670

you play golf, you make

bazillions of dollars.

00:38:29.670 --> 00:38:31.470

What is just and fair about that?

00:38:31.470 --> 00:38:32.303

Nothing.

00:38:32.303 --> 00:38:34.350

You gotta start from square one.

00:38:34.350 --> 00:38:35.183

- Start.

00:38:36.270 --> 00:38:37.103

Yeah.

00:38:40.760 --> 00:38:41.593

I\'m with you.

00:38:41.593 --> 00:38:42.870

- [Rebecca] Okay, thank you.

00:38:53.604 --> 00:38:55.620

- [Man] You have the logo on your shirt.

00:38:55.620 --> 00:38:56.480

- Yeah, that\'s the real logo

00:38:56.480 --> 00:38:58.533

not that fake Shinnecock Open logo.

00:38:59.550 --> 00:39:02.950

My grandmother was one of the

matriarchs of our community.

00:39:02.950 --> 00:39:04.640

She was born in 1889.

00:39:04.640 --> 00:39:07.980

I think one of the things

that she instilled in us,

00:39:07.980 --> 00:39:09.960

I had two uncles.

00:39:09.960 --> 00:39:10.793

They caddied.

00:39:10.793 --> 00:39:13.280

They used to caddy right

over here at Shinnecock Hills

00:39:13.280 --> 00:39:15.600

and everyday that we

rode on that golf course

00:39:15.600 --> 00:39:19.487

she would say to us \"Little

man, this is your land.

00:39:19.487 --> 00:39:23.977

\"This is our land and you

have to get this back for us.

00:39:23.977 --> 00:39:26.257

\"It\'s gonna be your

generation that does it.\"

00:39:27.600 --> 00:39:31.080

The land battle has been ongoing.

00:39:31.080 --> 00:39:36.080

From 1978 we started

this battle, this fight

00:39:36.760 --> 00:39:41.540

for recognition and land.

00:39:41.540 --> 00:39:46.240

In the last 15 years we

finally had enough funding

00:39:46.240 --> 00:39:47.937

to really fight it in court.

00:39:47.937 --> 00:39:51.580

- So it was 2005 that we first

00:39:51.580 --> 00:39:54.070

officially filed our land claim.

00:39:54.070 --> 00:39:55.690

- They\'re claiming latches.

00:39:55.690 --> 00:39:58.070

And what latches is, latches says that,

00:39:58.070 --> 00:40:00.110

well you waited too long.

00:40:00.110 --> 00:40:01.800

You didn\'t fight for it.

00:40:01.800 --> 00:40:04.500

And we\'re like, are you kidding?

00:40:04.500 --> 00:40:08.240

- And the equitable doctrine of latches,

00:40:08.240 --> 00:40:13.240

you can\'t disrupt the expectation

of current land owners

00:40:14.360 --> 00:40:19.310

and because the court of appeals

just dismissed our claims

00:40:19.310 --> 00:40:24.140

we weren\'t able to delve

into the facts of the case.

00:40:24.140 --> 00:40:28.400

So I put together a petition

for a writ of certiorari

00:40:28.400 --> 00:40:31.173

to the Supreme Court for our land claim.

00:40:32.420 --> 00:40:34.630

It\'s kind of the last way

00:40:34.630 --> 00:40:39.110

to really exhaust your

claim through the system.

00:40:39.110 --> 00:40:43.580

But the Supreme Court decided

not to review our claim.

00:40:43.580 --> 00:40:46.340

You know, in that sense it\'s still alive.

00:40:46.340 --> 00:40:48.883

If it was an unfavorable decision,

00:40:48.883 --> 00:40:52.920

that would really have ended our claim.

00:40:52.920 --> 00:40:55.580

But they didn\'t and because of that,

00:40:55.580 --> 00:40:59.418

we still have ways that

we can bring our claims.

00:40:59.418 --> 00:41:01.835

(soft music)

00:41:07.240 --> 00:41:08.503

- We have a saying.

00:41:11.810 --> 00:41:13.840

We have to preserve our way of life

00:41:13.840 --> 00:41:15.493

for the next seven generations.

00:41:17.850 --> 00:41:20.913

What that means is that we

have to understand who we are,

00:41:22.410 --> 00:41:24.110

we have to understand our history,

00:41:25.336 --> 00:41:27.936

and we have to be able to

tell that to our children.

00:41:29.430 --> 00:41:30.757

It was a famous quote.

00:41:30.757 --> 00:41:33.280

\"To save the man you

must kill the Indian.\"

00:41:33.280 --> 00:41:35.402

Meaning not literally kill the person

00:41:35.402 --> 00:41:37.390

but you have to kill the

Indian spirit inside of them.

00:41:37.390 --> 00:41:39.670

You have to kill their way of life

00:41:39.670 --> 00:41:42.013

and turn them into a civilized person.

00:41:43.923 --> 00:41:46.480

It was actually illegal in

the United States and Canada

00:41:46.480 --> 00:41:49.520

for Native Americans to

practice our cultures,

00:41:49.520 --> 00:41:51.200

for us to hold ceremonies,

00:41:51.200 --> 00:41:54.163

for us to wear our traditional regalia.

00:41:55.680 --> 00:41:58.330

They would say that we couldn\'t

have been worshiping God

00:41:58.330 --> 00:41:59.580

because we weren\'t Christian.

00:41:59.580 --> 00:42:01.680

So we must have been worshiping the Devil.

00:42:02.840 --> 00:42:07.370

We were forced to assimilate

to the colonized world

00:42:08.470 --> 00:42:11.823

due to what I call

institutionalized colonialism.

00:42:12.780 --> 00:42:15.230

A lot of culture was lost.

00:42:15.230 --> 00:42:16.800

A lot of our history was lost.

00:42:18.650 --> 00:42:21.090

- There used to be a stockade downtown

00:42:21.090 --> 00:42:25.120

and our people used to

be put in that stockade

00:42:25.120 --> 00:42:27.163

if we were caught speaking our language.

00:42:33.150 --> 00:42:35.670

- The Hamptons has its own

sense of its own history

00:42:35.670 --> 00:42:37.370

and who gets to tell that history?

00:42:39.600 --> 00:42:42.500

There are two ways that people

00:42:42.500 --> 00:42:44.943

who kind of come to an area

00:42:44.943 --> 00:42:48.520

and conquer and settle an area

00:42:48.520 --> 00:42:52.100

try to both imprint

their own identity on it

00:42:52.100 --> 00:42:53.510

and then naturalize it in a way

00:42:53.510 --> 00:42:55.290

as if they\'ve always been there.

00:42:55.290 --> 00:43:00.290

The first way is to establish

the aesthetic of their lives.

00:43:00.750 --> 00:43:02.860

They build buildings that

look like the buildings

00:43:02.860 --> 00:43:04.370

that they\'re used to.

00:43:04.370 --> 00:43:07.540

So you bring with you and

you build what you know.

00:43:07.540 --> 00:43:09.930

But eventually you need to suggest

00:43:09.930 --> 00:43:12.420

that this always was.

00:43:12.420 --> 00:43:14.930

You start to look at the history

00:43:14.930 --> 00:43:16.830

and who gets to tell the history

00:43:16.830 --> 00:43:19.100

and where do you start your history.

00:43:19.100 --> 00:43:22.830

You start to look at how things are named.

00:43:22.830 --> 00:43:25.540

You start to create a

kind of historical sense

00:43:25.540 --> 00:43:28.210

that this has always been your place,

00:43:28.210 --> 00:43:29.900

you are of this place.

00:43:29.900 --> 00:43:31.560

And so, if we\'re really going to have

00:43:31.560 --> 00:43:33.281

an accurate picture of history,

00:43:33.281 --> 00:43:36.280

whose voices aren\'t

being portrayed in this

00:43:36.280 --> 00:43:37.993

and what do they add to the story?

00:43:38.946 --> 00:43:41.529

(bell dinging)

00:43:58.110 --> 00:43:59.540

- The Southampton Town Board

00:43:59.540 --> 00:44:02.950

has made massive efforts to

protect their colonial sites

00:44:02.950 --> 00:44:04.560

and their colonial cemeteries,

00:44:04.560 --> 00:44:06.100

their colonial old houses

00:44:08.200 --> 00:44:11.040

but they don\'t make an effort to help us

00:44:11.040 --> 00:44:15.090

preserve our Native American

sensitive sacred sites.

00:44:15.090 --> 00:44:17.390

They just, they don\'t see it as the same.

00:44:17.390 --> 00:44:21.130

- The acquisition of lands

of Romeo in Shinnecock Hills.

00:44:21.130 --> 00:44:23.790

- We have been before you many many times

00:44:23.790 --> 00:44:26.880

and always have said the same thing.

00:44:26.880 --> 00:44:29.153

The goal is to preserve the 13 acres.

00:44:30.985 --> 00:44:32.235

Good afternoon.

00:44:33.460 --> 00:44:37.110

I am Rebecca Genia and this

is Nasha, my granddaughter.

00:44:37.110 --> 00:44:39.330

We\'re from the Shinnecock Indian Nation.

00:44:39.330 --> 00:44:42.190

I believe the town of

Southampton needs a reminder

00:44:42.190 --> 00:44:44.730

that life did not begin in 1640

00:44:44.730 --> 00:44:47.840

when the pilgrims arrived

on our shores from Europe.

00:44:47.840 --> 00:44:50.730

Native people lived on this

land in harmony with nature

00:44:50.730 --> 00:44:53.890

for thousands and thousands

of years before your arrival.

00:44:53.890 --> 00:44:54.990

- Public hearing number five

00:44:54.990 --> 00:44:57.890

to consider the acquisition

of lands of Parrish Pond.

00:44:57.890 --> 00:44:59.040

- The source of funding would be

00:44:59.040 --> 00:45:00.760

the Community Preservation Fund.

00:45:00.760 --> 00:45:03.370

- Those lots were historically sensitive

00:45:03.370 --> 00:45:05.190

and what they\'re planning to do with it

00:45:05.190 --> 00:45:06.890

to preserve it, does anybody know?

00:45:08.160 --> 00:45:10.590

- Today we\'re talking about preservation.

00:45:10.590 --> 00:45:12.510

Primarily land preservation

00:45:12.510 --> 00:45:14.610

and the Community Preservation Fund.

00:45:14.610 --> 00:45:16.280

- When property transfers,

00:45:16.280 --> 00:45:18.330

the buyer pays 2% of the purchase price

00:45:18.330 --> 00:45:19.580

into a dedicated fund.

00:45:19.580 --> 00:45:22.950

- This 2% tax has been

generating quite a bit of money.

00:45:22.950 --> 00:45:24.460

- In the town of Southampton alone

00:45:24.460 --> 00:45:27.842

the fund has generated

over $700 million, yes.

00:45:27.842 --> 00:45:28.722

- Right.

00:45:28.722 --> 00:45:30.960

Wow, $700 million.

- Yes.

00:45:30.960 --> 00:45:32.500

Previous to the 1990\'s,

00:45:32.500 --> 00:45:37.130

there was your small year

round population here

00:45:37.130 --> 00:45:41.010

as well as your summer resort homeowners.

00:45:41.010 --> 00:45:42.750

I think in the 1990\'s,

00:45:42.750 --> 00:45:46.433

Wall Street started to sort of get bigger.

00:45:47.920 --> 00:45:51.933

The Hamptons became an

attractive place to have equity.

00:45:52.820 --> 00:45:54.770

- With the pace of development

00:45:54.770 --> 00:45:57.120

we\'re losing open spaces.

00:45:57.120 --> 00:46:00.200

Woodlands, which are an important habitat.

00:46:00.200 --> 00:46:01.510

We\'re losing farmland,

00:46:01.510 --> 00:46:05.800

which was part of our

agricultural character.

00:46:05.800 --> 00:46:09.540

So we started to buy a

lot of these properties.

00:46:09.540 --> 00:46:13.300

It really kind of protected

our rural character.

00:46:13.300 --> 00:46:16.190

- People who spend a lot

of money on homes out here

00:46:16.190 --> 00:46:18.320

really love to drive past farmland.

00:46:18.320 --> 00:46:19.730

Community Preservation Fund

00:46:19.730 --> 00:46:21.870

was to preserve our community character

00:46:21.870 --> 00:46:25.300

which is defined, in part,

with our scenic landscapes.

00:46:25.300 --> 00:46:27.870

- You know, one of the

things that accompanies

00:46:27.870 --> 00:46:30.330

this new wave out to the Hamptons

00:46:30.330 --> 00:46:31.970

is a kind of aesthetic

00:46:31.970 --> 00:46:34.683

that really creates a new sense of nature.

00:46:36.160 --> 00:46:38.160

If you look at some of the photography

00:46:38.160 --> 00:46:40.260

of the disappearing farms

00:46:40.260 --> 00:46:42.820

and there\'s this kind of

romanticization of the farms

00:46:42.820 --> 00:46:45.300

at the same time that

farms are becoming vistas

00:46:45.300 --> 00:46:46.450

and not working farms.

00:46:46.450 --> 00:46:48.940

They don\'t produce food, right?

00:46:48.940 --> 00:46:50.630

They produce views.

00:46:50.630 --> 00:46:52.070

Photographers kind of create

00:46:52.070 --> 00:46:54.600

this whole nostalgia around the farms

00:46:54.600 --> 00:46:56.270

at the same time that they kind of

00:46:56.270 --> 00:46:58.290

naturalize their extinction.

00:46:58.290 --> 00:47:00.610

It really turns farms into this

00:47:00.610 --> 00:47:04.070

kind of caricature of

something that\'s historical.

00:47:04.070 --> 00:47:04.940

And on the other hand,

00:47:04.940 --> 00:47:07.690

it\'s a distortion of the

historical narrative itself

00:47:07.690 --> 00:47:10.250

because it suggests that

the farms themselves

00:47:10.250 --> 00:47:12.070

are what\'s indigenous to the place.

00:47:12.070 --> 00:47:14.140

And of course, the farms only represent

00:47:14.140 --> 00:47:16.970

that wave of conqueror

that clear cut the land

00:47:16.970 --> 00:47:19.050

and destroy the Native American economy

00:47:19.050 --> 00:47:20.290

and brought in their own kind

00:47:20.290 --> 00:47:22.143

of commercial agricultural economy.

00:47:29.793 --> 00:47:32.730

- Shinnecocks do alert me to properties

00:47:32.730 --> 00:47:34.640

that they think are important.

00:47:34.640 --> 00:47:38.050

They will get involved,

particularly for a subdivision

00:47:38.050 --> 00:47:40.510

on a property that they feel is important

00:47:40.510 --> 00:47:42.390

to explore preservation.

00:47:42.390 --> 00:47:44.680

It has to do with timing and persistence

00:47:44.680 --> 00:47:46.733

and also with the Shinnecock Tribe members

00:47:46.733 --> 00:47:50.040

educating land owners and helping them

00:47:50.040 --> 00:47:52.890

to understand why it\'s important.

00:47:52.890 --> 00:47:56.140

- We\'ve been able to preserve,

00:47:56.140 --> 00:47:59.760

I think it\'s less than 20 acres of land,

00:47:59.760 --> 00:48:01.910

fighting tooth and nail

00:48:01.910 --> 00:48:03.410

telling them these are graves,

00:48:03.410 --> 00:48:05.870

we have to protect them,

this is sacred land,

00:48:05.870 --> 00:48:08.290

this is ancient burials.

00:48:08.290 --> 00:48:11.190

New York is one of four

states in the whole country

00:48:11.190 --> 00:48:13.672

that don\'t have graves protection laws.

00:48:13.672 --> 00:48:15.830

(thrilling music)

00:48:15.830 --> 00:48:17.450

- [Reporter] Walter

Richards of Shelter Island

00:48:17.450 --> 00:48:19.480

speaks with awe about the

discovery he unearthed

00:48:19.480 --> 00:48:22.130

on the grounds of his Osprey Road home.

00:48:22.130 --> 00:48:24.110

A mass grave containing the remains

00:48:24.110 --> 00:48:25.770

of Native American Indians.

00:48:25.770 --> 00:48:28.230

Skeletal remains buried in fetal positions

00:48:28.230 --> 00:48:30.930

about four feet into the ground.

00:48:30.930 --> 00:48:33.730

- It\'s not too late and it\'s

not over till it\'s over.

00:48:33.730 --> 00:48:36.080

There\'s not one foundation up there yet.

00:48:36.080 --> 00:48:40.300

- A horse barn was built

over a massive grave site

00:48:40.300 --> 00:48:42.620

on private property.

00:48:42.620 --> 00:48:44.480

Despite the good intentions

00:48:44.480 --> 00:48:48.320

and the good will of

individuals and town people,

00:48:48.320 --> 00:48:50.917

they went ahead and built it.

00:48:54.453 --> 00:48:55.630

You have a known grave site,

00:48:55.630 --> 00:48:59.860

you have a known, it\'s on

county land or public land,

00:48:59.860 --> 00:49:04.490

there are laws, there

are rules and regulations

00:49:04.490 --> 00:49:06.660

in place to protect those sites

00:49:06.660 --> 00:49:10.600

but if they\'re on private land,

then it\'s a different story.

00:49:10.600 --> 00:49:11.970

- Everybody watches Discovery Channel.

00:49:11.970 --> 00:49:12.803

We thought this was something

00:49:12.803 --> 00:49:14.800

that was gonna be really neat

00:49:14.800 --> 00:49:15.910

and be able to uncover.

00:49:15.910 --> 00:49:17.810

We had a really good time uncovering it

00:49:17.810 --> 00:49:19.200

and looking at everything and studying it.

00:49:19.200 --> 00:49:21.510

It was a real, it was really exciting.

00:49:21.510 --> 00:49:23.200

We thought it would be

in the best interest

00:49:23.200 --> 00:49:25.097

of the remains to be encased

00:49:25.097 --> 00:49:28.000

within the four walls of our structure

00:49:28.000 --> 00:49:30.240

and basically preserved forever.

00:49:30.240 --> 00:49:32.800

Which when you get into the whole,

00:49:32.800 --> 00:49:34.880

which that\'s when things went awry

00:49:34.880 --> 00:49:38.650

because we didn\'t know

that their belief system

00:49:38.650 --> 00:49:40.460

was not similar to our belief system

00:49:40.460 --> 00:49:43.930

where we bury people in

concrete vaults all the time.

00:49:43.930 --> 00:49:46.550

- Don\'t imagine how we feel.

00:49:46.550 --> 00:49:50.523

Imagine how you would feel if it were you.

00:49:53.210 --> 00:49:57.750

- Shelter Island prompted us

to start writing legislation.

00:49:57.750 --> 00:50:00.550

- When these issues are

brought to our attention

00:50:00.550 --> 00:50:02.800

we address them like a fire drill.

00:50:02.800 --> 00:50:05.760

Seeing that, the Shinnecocks have proposed

00:50:05.760 --> 00:50:09.460

that there be a systematized

approach to this,

00:50:09.460 --> 00:50:12.120

namely a colonial and Native Americans

00:50:12.120 --> 00:50:14.080

graves preservation act.

00:50:14.080 --> 00:50:17.120

- This draft has been with

the Southampton Town Board

00:50:17.120 --> 00:50:20.080

probably since 2003.

00:50:20.080 --> 00:50:22.720

You know, archeologists have helped.

00:50:22.720 --> 00:50:25.430

Over the past 13 years or so,

00:50:25.430 --> 00:50:27.830

every time we go to the

Southampton Town Board,

00:50:27.830 --> 00:50:29.720

okay well here\'s another draft.

00:50:29.720 --> 00:50:31.370

We\'ll have to run it by the attorney.

00:50:31.370 --> 00:50:36.370

We have, we\'re probably on

our fourth town supervisor.

00:50:36.880 --> 00:50:37.713

- George.

00:50:37.713 --> 00:50:39.100

- I think the real experts on this

00:50:39.100 --> 00:50:41.256

are sitting in front of

you, the Shinnecocks.

00:50:41.256 --> 00:50:42.089

- [Board Member] Of course.

00:50:42.089 --> 00:50:44.420

- What you said to us in

the following phone calls

00:50:44.420 --> 00:50:45.940

is that it\'s in the attorney\'s hands.

00:50:45.940 --> 00:50:47.696

What has your attorney come up with

00:50:47.696 --> 00:50:51.620

in four and a half years

of reviewing this draft

00:50:51.620 --> 00:50:52.843

of graves protection?

00:50:53.930 --> 00:50:55.290

- There is a working draft

00:50:55.290 --> 00:50:57.900

but it\'s been through at least

three different attorneys.

00:50:57.900 --> 00:51:00.140

- We\'ve been through many supervisors,

00:51:00.140 --> 00:51:01.470

many different board members,

00:51:01.470 --> 00:51:03.570

many different town attorneys,

00:51:03.570 --> 00:51:05.150

and everybody has the same story.

00:51:05.150 --> 00:51:08.020

Oh, we\'re looking into

it and we\'ll, you know,

00:51:08.020 --> 00:51:09.489

pass it by the attorneys.

00:51:09.489 --> 00:51:10.790

- The people that buy the property

00:51:10.790 --> 00:51:11.810

don\'t know the property.

00:51:11.810 --> 00:51:13.460

They only see the value.

00:51:13.460 --> 00:51:14.510

I don\'t blame them for that.

00:51:14.510 --> 00:51:16.430

That\'s all we show them.

00:51:16.430 --> 00:51:19.530

Southampton Town needs

to say there\'s graves.

00:51:19.530 --> 00:51:21.746

If you find one, you\'re moving your house,

00:51:21.746 --> 00:51:23.070

you\'re moving your driveway.

- Okay, but I wanna

00:51:23.070 --> 00:51:24.040

get you there legally.

00:51:24.040 --> 00:51:25.550

- Legally.

- Okay.

00:51:25.550 --> 00:51:27.150

And we\'ve talked about this

00:51:27.150 --> 00:51:29.520

and I know it\'s all

cumbersome and complicated

00:51:29.520 --> 00:51:32.130

and I\'m asking my town attorney

to please pay attention

00:51:32.130 --> 00:51:34.550

so that you can move it through

the town attorney\'s office.

00:51:34.550 --> 00:51:37.660

- It\'s only complicated because

you\'ve never done it before.

00:51:37.660 --> 00:51:38.860

It\'s not complicated.

00:51:38.860 --> 00:51:39.800

This is very simple.

00:51:39.800 --> 00:51:41.350

If you want it done, you do it.

00:51:41.350 --> 00:51:42.930

And anyone who buys property here

00:51:42.930 --> 00:51:46.240

that is part of the gamble they take

00:51:46.240 --> 00:51:47.690

when they buy a piece of property

00:51:47.690 --> 00:51:48.523

in the town of Southampton.

00:51:48.523 --> 00:51:50.793

And it can be done at your next meeting.

00:51:50.793 --> 00:51:51.626

- I understand what

00:51:51.626 --> 00:51:52.459

you\'re saying.

- Well if it\'s that simple,

00:51:52.459 --> 00:51:53.670

we will try it but I\'m telling you,

00:51:53.670 --> 00:51:55.050

I don\'t think it\'s that simple.

00:51:55.050 --> 00:51:56.710

- Now, on private property there\'s a law

00:51:56.710 --> 00:51:59.550

that you can\'t bury a person.

00:51:59.550 --> 00:52:01.680

I don\'t see how it\'s so hard to have a law

00:52:01.680 --> 00:52:04.302

that says you can\'t dig up a person.

00:52:04.302 --> 00:52:06.600

Some things are as simple

as that, they really are.

00:52:06.600 --> 00:52:08.500

- We\'re not going to settle for this

00:52:08.500 --> 00:52:11.730

each and every single

time a grave is unearthed.

00:52:11.730 --> 00:52:13.810

- So within a month we\'re gonna regroup,

00:52:13.810 --> 00:52:15.910

we\'re gonna give our

town attorney some time.

00:52:15.910 --> 00:52:17.110

We will get back to you

00:52:17.110 --> 00:52:19.270

and Becky is, you\'re our main point person

00:52:19.270 --> 00:52:21.770

for heading up the task force.

00:52:49.150 --> 00:52:51.100

- A number of you have come to approach

00:52:51.100 --> 00:52:56.100

the board of Native American

Graves Burial Site Protection.

00:52:57.552 --> 00:52:59.583

- If you all could just, pass it on.

00:53:00.721 --> 00:53:03.770

We\'re on our fourth supervisor since 2003

00:53:03.770 --> 00:53:08.420

and we have not really

gotten too much of anywhere.

00:53:08.420 --> 00:53:10.130

- You\'re saying the owner\'s rights

00:53:10.130 --> 00:53:13.750

are over yours, is that,

presently and you\'re looking to--

00:53:13.750 --> 00:53:16.590

- Yes, go over the rights of

the desecration of the grave.

00:53:16.590 --> 00:53:19.560

- Do we have a committee for relationships

00:53:19.560 --> 00:53:21.700

between the Shinnecock

Nation and the town?

00:53:21.700 --> 00:53:22.730

- No.

- All right.

00:53:22.730 --> 00:53:23.563

Probably is a good idea

00:53:23.563 --> 00:53:26.320

whether it would be twice a year

00:53:26.320 --> 00:53:27.777

or something like that, I don\'t know.

00:53:27.777 --> 00:53:28.610

- I don\'t either

00:53:28.610 --> 00:53:32.550

but in order for us to

accomplish certain things

00:53:34.000 --> 00:53:36.250

we have to kind of keep it separate.

00:53:36.250 --> 00:53:37.170

- I just wanna make sure,

00:53:37.170 --> 00:53:39.120

today you\'re speaking as a representative

00:53:39.120 --> 00:53:41.470

of the Shinnecock Nation

or as an individual?

00:53:41.470 --> 00:53:44.620

- I am on the Shinnecock

Archeological Advisory Committee,

00:53:44.620 --> 00:53:46.740

the, so I don\'t know what you\'re asking.

00:53:46.740 --> 00:53:47.573

- We just wanna know if this is--

00:53:47.573 --> 00:53:50.850

- Plus I am general counselor.

- Your position today,

00:53:50.850 --> 00:53:53.070

is it an official position

00:53:53.070 --> 00:53:54.930

of the Shinnecock Nation

00:53:54.930 --> 00:53:56.960

or is an individual position?

- I am an official

00:53:56.960 --> 00:53:58.710

representative of the Shinnecock

00:53:58.710 --> 00:54:00.920

Archeological Advisory Committee

00:54:00.920 --> 00:54:04.830

and I\'m no stranger, maybe

to you all because I predate,

00:54:04.830 --> 00:54:07.530

I don\'t really remember anybody\'s face.

00:54:07.530 --> 00:54:08.540

- So I just wanna make sure

00:54:08.540 --> 00:54:10.147

you\'re speaking on behalf of the nation.

00:54:10.147 --> 00:54:12.350

- [Rebecca] And I have been since 2003

00:54:12.350 --> 00:54:14.000

and it\'s in black and white

right in front of you.

00:54:14.000 --> 00:54:16.530

Okay, thank you.

- Okay, appreciate it.

00:54:16.530 --> 00:54:18.500

- We think a simple procedure

00:54:18.500 --> 00:54:21.070

to protect these inadvertent discoveries.

00:54:21.070 --> 00:54:22.270

- [Jay] You know what my fear is, right?

00:54:22.270 --> 00:54:23.103

- I know what it is.

00:54:23.103 --> 00:54:24.410

- That a developer, not, you know,

00:54:24.410 --> 00:54:25.980

developers are good people, you know?

00:54:25.980 --> 00:54:30.980

But that if we make the

process too onerous,

00:54:31.010 --> 00:54:32.600

that they\'re not gonna tell us.
